Graphical abstract Methanol synthesis by CO2 reduction is an important approach for energy storage. Aiming at a reduction of the catalyst mass in technical applications, we have investigated the influence of increasing Au loading on the performance of Au/ZnO in methanol and CO formation from CO2 reduction. Using the same type of ZnO support, increased Au loading resulted also in a pronounced increase in Au particle size. The Au-mass-normalized reaction rate for methanol formation and TOF decrease with increasing Au loading/particle size, while the selectivity for methanol formation increases. CO adsorption monitored by in situ FTIR revealed a pronounced decrease of the accessible Au surface area during reaction, independent of the Au loading, pointing to a partial encapsulation of the Au nanoparticles by a partly reduced ZnOx, as described by SMSI effects. Possible reasons responsible for these effects and Au loading/size effects therein are discussed, strategies for future work are outlined. Keywords CO2 reduction Green methanol O-vacancy Metal nanoparticle encapsulation Selectivity control Au particle size effect 1 Introduction Methanol synthesis from CO2 reduction (CO2 + 3H2 ↔ CH3OH; ΔH298K, 50 bar = -90.7 kJ mol−1) using hydrogen generated with renewable energies is one of the most important catalytic processes when aiming at the utilization of renewable energies [1–3]. In a so-called “methanol economy”, methanol is not only seen as a platform chemical for the production of value-added chemicals, but is also used for synthetic fuel production and for storing excess electric energy (“chemical energy storage”). Currently, industrial methanol synthesis is mostly based on syngas containing limited amounts of CO2, using Cu-ZnO based catalysts [4–6]. These catalysts are also active for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol; in this reaction they suffer, however, from a low selectivity for methanol formation, due to their considerable activity for CO formation via the reverse water-gas shift reaction (CO2 + H2 ↔ CO + H2O) [7,8]. Previous studies have demonstrated that supported Au catalysts, in particular Au/ZnO catalysts, are promising catalysts for methanol synthesis from CO2 and H2 under moderate reaction conditions, which show a significantly higher selectivity for methanol formation compared to Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 under similar reaction conditions, while keeping a comparable noble metal mass-normalized activity for methanol formation [8–12]. While these studies generated valuable insights on fundamental aspects of the reaction, a number of points important for technical applications, but also for a more detailed mechanistic understanding, have not been tackled so far. For instance, most of these studies have been performed under conditions of low CO2 conversion, by limiting the amount of active catalyst, where thermodynamic effects on the measured reaction kinetics are negligible and where the formation of side products such as H2O or CO, via the reverse water gas shift reaction, is also low and can in a first-order approximation be neglected. For technically desirable high conversions this is no longer the case, and we have recently shown that the presence of CO in the feed gas mixture indeed lowers the methanol formation rate [11]. Another important aspect would be the effect of Au loading, of the Au particle size and of the particle size / specific surface area of the ZnO support. For instance, Sakurai et al. reported that the Au particle size significantly affects the reaction, with the activity for methanol formation decreasing with increasing Au particle size (5–20 nm) [9]. On the other hand, in a later study, we could demonstrate that increasing Au particle size (3–10 nm) results in a pronounced increase of the selectivity for methanol formation [11]. In these cases, the Au loading was fixed, and the Au particle size was varied by controlled calcination. It should be noted, however, that this treatment also results in an increase of the ZnO particle sizes and the decrease of the specific surface area of the Au/ZnO catalysts. Strunk et al. demonstrated that increasing the Au loading from 1 to 3 wt.%, while keeping the Au particle size and the specific surface area of the catalyst essentially constant, results in an increasing formation of O-vacancies and, though less pronounced, increase of the CO conversion in a 15 % CO/H2 gas mixture [10]. They concluded that O-vacancy sites, most likely at the perimeter sites of the Au nanoparticles, are the active sites for methanol formation and that the presence of the Au particles enhances the number of exposed O-vacancies in ZnO compared to pristine ZnO under identical reaction condition [10]. In a recent study, we could spectroscopically identify the partial reduction of ZnO during reaction and the re-oxidation of reduced ZnO in the presence of CO2 on a Au/ZnO catalyst by switching the reaction gas from a CO/H2 to a CO2/H2 mixture, and demonstrate that O-vacancies play a central role in CO2 reduction to methanol [12,13]. Re-oxidation of O-vacancies by reaction with CO2 was also reported in a theoretical study by Fink [14]. Furthermore, we found that increasing the ZnO particle size of Au/ZnO catalysts (22–103 nm), while keeping the Au loading / Au particle size constant, leads to a continuous increase of their selectivity for methanol formation [15]. In contrast, their activity for methanol formation was found to pass through a maximum in a volcano-type behavior. These reaction characteristics were explained by a competition between electronic metal-support interactions (EMSIs), due to charge transfer from O-vacancies in ZnOx to adjacent Au sites in the Au NPs, and strong metal-support interaction (SMSI), resulting in partial overgrowth of the Au NPs by a ZnOx layer [15]. In total, these studies could clearly demonstrate that Au loading, Au particle size, and also the particle size / specific surface area of the ZnO support play a crucial role in the methanol synthesis from CO2/H2 mixtures, and most likely will also interfere with each other. Interestingly, the situation commonly experienced in deposition-precipitation procedures, where varying the metal loading mostly also leads to a substantial increase of the metal particle size, while the support particle size is kept constant, had not been covered so far. This is the topic of the present work, where we investigated changes in the CO2 reduction behavior of Au/ZnO catalysts upon varying the Au loading between 1 and 16.5 wt.%, which is found to result also in substantial changes in Au particle size, while the specific surface area of the catalysts was essentially constant. First, we will illustrate the performance of the different catalysts for methanol and CO formation from CO2 reduction under different high pressures from 5–50 bar at 240 °C. Second, we will present and discuss the results of the structural characterization of the catalysts and possible reaction-induced changes therein obtained from by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (STEM). Next, we characterize the CO adsorption properties of the Au nanoparticles, including both the amount and the vibrational characteristics of the COad species, in low-temperature CO adsorption measurements on the freshly calcined Au/ZnO catalysts and on the spent Au/ZnO catalysts, employing in situ diffuse reflectance FTIR (DRIFTS) for characterization. Possible differences in the surface composition of the catalysts and reaction-induced changes therein were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). In combination, these measurements will provide information about possible changes in the accessible surface area of the Au NPs and thus on possible overgrowth / encapsulation due to SMSI effects. Finally, consequences of these results on the detailed understanding of the role of Au/ZnO catalysts in these reactions are summarized and discussed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis We prepared Au/ZnO catalysts with different Au: ZnO ratios but similar specific surface area by a deposition-precipitation (DP) method, using both a commercial ZnO material (Sigma-Aldrich) and a synthesized ZnO material with identical structure and comparable crystallite sizes. The self-made ZnO was synthesized by a precipitation method. An aqueous solution (200 mL) of Zn(NO3)2 (20 mmol) was stirred at 70 °C and poured into an aqueous solution of Na2CO3 (0.12 M, 200 mL) under vigorous stirring at 70 °C. The suspension was aged at 70 °C for 1 h and then washed with distilled water (40 °C), until the pH of the supernatant was stabilized. The precipitate was filtered and dried at 80 °C overnight. The dried precipitate was calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. For the 1.0 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst, we dissolved HAuCl4 in 100 mL of deionized distilled water at 70 °C, while the pH of the solution was adjusted to 4 using a 1 M NaOH solution. Afterwards, we added 2 g of the synthesized ZnO into the solution, now adjusting the pH of the dispersed solution to 7 using a NaOH solution. The suspension was stirred for 1 h while keeping the pH value and the temperature (70 °C). Then, the precipitate was washed with deionized water (at a temperature of 40 °C) for 5 times. No residual Cl was detected by XPS in the Au/ZnO catalysts. Finally, the precipitate was filtered, dried at 80 °C overnight, and then the powder was calcined in air at 300 °C for 4 h. The calcined catalysts were stored in a fridge until use. The 9.5 wt.% Au/ZnO and 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO samples were prepared by a urea-based DP procedure. HAuCl4 equivalent to 10 wt.% and 20 wt.% were used for preparation, respectively. HAuCl4, urea (urea/Au = 200 by molar ratio), and the commercial ZnO material (1.2 g) were mixed in H2O (150 mL) and stirred at 95 °C for 4 h. The subsequent procedure was the same as above. 2.2 Catalytic measurements The kinetic experiments were performed in a fixed-bed glass-lined stainless steel micro-reactor (length: 25 cm, inner diameter: 0.4 cm) at pressures between 5 and 50 bar at 240 °C under a continuous flow of CO2/H2 (1:3) gas mixtures, with a total gas flow of 30 Nml min−1 in all measurements. The reaction gases were prepared using high-pressure mass flow controllers (Brooks Instrument SLA5850). The total pressure was controlled using a backpressure controller (Tescom ER 5000). In total, about 200 mg of the pure Au/ZnO catalyst was used, resulting in a catalyst bed length of ∼1.2 cm, After calcination (in 10 % O2/N2 at 400 °C for 60 min), the reaction rates were evaluated at different pressures between 5 bar and 50 bar (Section 3.1). The influent and effluent gases were analyzed by online gas chromatography (DANI 86.10), using thermal conductivity detectors (carrier gas H2) and a standard test gas mixture for calibration (CO detection limit ca. 5 ppm, methanol detection limit ca. 20 ppm). All measurements were performed under differential reaction conditions, in the range of low conversions (<1.6 %). This is also well below the level required for reaching thermodynamic equilibrium (∼23 % CO2 conversion at 240 °C, 50 bar total pressure in the current reaction gas mixture: 15 % CO2, 45 % H2, 40 % Ar), when considering methanol synthesis and the reverse water gas shift reaction (resulting equilibrium composition: 12.0 % CO2, 38.7 % H2, 1.4 % CO, 2.3 % CH3OH, 3.7 % H2O and 41.9 % Ar) [16]. Based on the molar product flow rates of MeOH (n MeOH,out) or CO (n CO,out) and the weight of Au metal (mAu), the Au-mass-normalized MeOH (RMeOH) and CO (RCO) formation rates were calculated according to Eqs. (1) and (2). From the Au mass-normalized rates, the atomic mass of Au (196.966 g mol−1), and the Au dispersion (DAu) obtained from STEM imaging (see below), turnover frequencies (TOFs) were calculated according to Eq. (3). The selectivity for MeOH formation (SMeOH), defined as the ratio of the MeOH formation rate to the overall CO2 hydrogenation rate to MeOH and CO, was calculated via Eq. (4). (1) R M e O H = n M e O H , o u t m A u (2) R C O = n C O , o u t m A u (3) T O F = R M e O H × M A u D A u (4) S M e O H = R M e O H R C O 2 = R M e O H R M e O H + R C O Note that the TOFs calculated this way represent effective values, as they i) refer to all Au surface atoms as active sites and ii) do not include loss of accessible surface area during the reaction due to partial overgrowth by a ZnOx layer (see Section 3.4). 2.3 Catalyst characterization 2.3.1 Au loading and surface area of the catalysts The Au loadings and the specific surface areas of the Au/ZnO catalysts were determined by atomic absorption spectrometry (AAS) measurements (Shimadzu AA-6200) and N2 physisorption measurements (BET method, Quantachrome QuadrasorbSI). 2.3.2 Electron Microscopy (EM) The Au particle sizes were determined from high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images, which were obtained on two instruments, a JEOL scanning electron transmission microscope (JEM-3200FS) and a Cs-corrected FEI electron microscope (Titan), which were both equipped with a high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) detector. Both microscopes were operated at an acceleration voltage of 300 kV. For detailed information on the Au particle size (volume-area mean diameter and particle size distribution), at least 400 particles were evaluated for each sample. 2.3.3 Dispersion of the Au NPs The Au dispersion DAu, which is defined by the ratio of accessible surface atoms to the total number of atoms in the l metal particles, was calculated from the volume-area mean diameter dVA, assuming hemispherical Au nanoparticles (NPs) and a surface density of 1.15 × 1015 Au atoms cm−2. dVA was determined according to Eq. (5) from the diameters (di) of the individual Au NPs (ni), as measured by HAADF-STEM. The Au metal dispersion was then calculated via Eq. (6). (5) d V A = ∑ i n i d i 3 ∑ i n i d i 2 (6) D A u = 6 V A u / a A u d V A with VAu being the volume of a Au atom, and aAu the surface area of a Au atom. 2.3.4 X-ray diffraction (XRD) XRD measurements of the ZnO oxides and Au/ZnO catalysts after reaction at high pressures at 240 °C in CO2/H2 gas mixture were performed on a Philips PANalytical X′Pert diffractometer, using a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.154 nm). The ZnO crystallite sizes were estimated via the Scherrer Eq. (7), using the reflection of the (101) plane of ZnO. K is a dimensionless shape factor, ∼0.89. (7) D Z n O = K × λ F W H M × cos θ 2.3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XP spectra were recorded on a PHI 5800 ESCA system (Physical Electronics), using monochromatized Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). The pass energy for survey spectra was 93.9 eV, for detail spectra we used 29.35 eV. The binding energies (BEs) of all spectra were calibrated with respect to the Zn (2p3/2) peak of ZnO oxide, which was fixed at a binding energy of 1021.5 eV, identical to the values obtained in our previous studies. This results in a binding energy of 285.0 eV for the C 1s peak of ubiquitous carbon. The deconvolution of the XP spectra was performed using a public XPS peak fitting program (XPSPEAK4.1). 2.3.6 In situ diffuse reflectance FTIR spectroscopy (DRIFTS) in situ DRIFTS measurements were performed on a Nicolet iS-50 FTIR spectrometer equipped with an in situ DRIFTS high-pressure reaction cell (HVC-DRP-4, Harrick Scientific). The DRIFTS spectra were measured with a resolution of 4 cm−1 (400 scans recorded per spectrum for each 15 min), using a MCT narrow band detector. The catalyst bed was prepared by depositing about 20 mg of pure catalyst on a 100 mg α-Al2O3 layer, which is inert in this reaction under present reaction conditions. Further catalyst treatment is described in the following CO adsorption paragraph. 2.3.7 Low-temperature CO adsorption After calcination at 400 °C in 10 % O2/N2, the calcined catalysts were purged in N2 for 60 min to remove water on the catalysts. The same procedure was applied after reaction in CO2/H2 gas mixture at 240 °C (total pressure 5–50 bar), to remove adsorbed CO, weakly bound hydrocarbons and adsorbed H2O / OH species from the catalyst. Low-temperature CO adsorption experiments were subsequently performed on these catalysts by exposing the catalyst bed to a continuous flow of 1 % CO/N2 at −140 °C, after cooling the reaction cell with liquid N2 in a flow of N2 for 1 h to reach steady-state. Prior to the CO adsorption experiment, background spectra were recorded on the catalysts at −140 °C under a flow of N2 (30 Nml min−1). To get normalized DRIFT spectra, the spectra recorded during CO adsorption were divided by the corresponding background spectrum. The intensities of the absorption signals were evaluated in Kubelka − Munk units (KMU), derived from the reflectance, R ν , via Eq. (8), which are generally proportional to the adsorbate concentration [17,18]. The layer of active catalyst can be considered as infinitely thick for the IR radiation, as assumed for the Kubelka-Munk evaluation. (8) KMU ν = (1 − R ν )2/2R ν Note that in all spectra presented contributions of the gas-phase CO signal (2040 - 2240 cm−1) were removed by subtracting a spectrum that was collected on pure α-Al2O3 powder under an identical CO-containing atmosphere at the same temperature. This way only adsorbed CO species are visible in the spectra presented. 3 Results and discussions Three Au/ZnO catalysts with Au loadings of 1.0 wt.%, 9.5 wt.%, and 16.5 wt.% were prepared and characterized in detail. 3.1 Activity and selectivity The catalytic activity and selectivity of the three Au/ZnO catalysts in the CO2 reduction reaction were measured in a standard CO2/H2 (1:3) gas mixture (15 % CO2, 45 % H2, balance Ar) at 240 °C. The reaction was performed according to the following sequence after calcination in 10 % O2/N2: i) reaction at a pressure of 5 bar for ∼1000 min, ii) then the pressure was stepwise increased up to 50 bar, following the reaction for ∼120 min at pressures of 10 bar, 20 bar, 40 bar, and finally for ∼1000 min at 50 bar. The CO2 conversion of three Au/ZnO catalysts during reaction at pressures from 5–50 bar are essentially similar (Fig. S1, Supplementary Material). For all Au/ZnO catalysts the CO2 conversion is below 1.6 % even at 50 bar, well below the equilibrium conversion over the whole range of pressures measured (see Section 2.2). As an example, at 240 °C and a total pressure of 50 bar, the CO2 conversions are 1.54 %, 1.36 % and 1.54 % for the 1.0 wt.%, 9.5 wt% and 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalysts, respectively. Hence, these data were acquired under kinetically controlled conditions and the evaluation of rates could assume differential reaction conditions. Furthermore, the significant differences in the selectivity for methanol formation on the three Au/ZnO catalysts are not due to differences in conversion. For all three Au/ZnO catalysts we found an initial activation phase (∼100 min) for methanol formation (CO2 + 3 H2 => CH3OH + H2O) at 5 bar. Initially the first sample was taken about 10 min after starting the reaction, the methanol formation rates were essentially zero, and increased after that. Hence, the activation was most pronounced for the 1 wt.% catalyst and significantly less for the high-loading catalysts (based on Au-mass normalized methanol formation rates). In the initial phase, CO formation prevails. The observation of an activation phase resembles previous findings for a commercial Au/ZnO catalyst (1 wt.% Au loading, surface area: 45 m2 g−1) [12,13]. In that case, the activation was found to go along with the formation of O-vacancies in the ZnO support during the reaction. This correlation was also supported by temporal analysis of products (TAP) reactor studies [19]. After the initial activation phase, we did not detect any measurable deactivation of the Au/ZnO catalysts at 5 bar (Fig. 1 a). The resulting steady-state Au-mass-normalized methanol formation rates decrease strongly with increasing Au loading, reaching rather low values for the high-loading catalysts (Table 1 ). In contrast, the catalyst-mass-normalized methanol formation rates of the three Au/ZnO catalysts are almost similar, around 5.0 × 10-8 molMeOH g−1 catalyst s−1. This surprising result and possible reasons for that will be discussed in more detail in Section 3.4. Effective turnover frequencies, (TOFs), calculated based on the accessible surface area of the Au NPs assuming hemispherical particle shape and the mean particle size derived from STEM measurements after reaction (Tables 2 and S1), show similar trends as the Au-mass-normalized rates (Table 1), although the effects are less pronounced. Also this will be discussed in more detail in Section 3.4. For the competing CO formation via the RWGS reaction (CO2+ H2 => CO + H2O), the 1 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst showed a slight deactivation at 5 bar, from ∼7.3 μmolCO gAu −1 s−1 to a stable rate of ∼6.1 μmolCO gAu −1 s−1 in 60 min, while the 9.5 wt.% and 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalysts both showed a stable rate of ∼0.1 μmolCO gAu −1 s−1. Based on the steady-state rates for methanol and CO formation, the resulting selectivities for methanol formation are significantly higher for the 9.5 and 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalysts (around 80 %), respectively, than for the 1.0 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst (43.7 %) (details see Table 1). The higher selectivities for methanol formation with increasing Au loading / Au particle size mainly result from the lower activity for CO formation, while the differences in the MeOH formation rate are considerable, but less pronounced. For all Au/ZnO catalysts, the methanol formation rate increased with increasing total pressure up to 40 bar and remained constant for 50 bar (Fig. 2 a). In contrast, for the CO formation rate, this (relative) increase was less pronounced compared to the methanol formation rate for the 1.0 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst, about similar for the 9.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst and even higher for the 16.5 % Au/ZnO catalyst. Except for the 9.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst the CO formation rate declined when changing to 50 bar (Fig. 2b). The respective steady-state effective TOFs, rates and selectivities are given in Table 1. Most important, the selectivity for methanol formation of the 1.0 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst increased from 43.7 % at 5 bar to 65.7 % at 50 bar, and a similar trend, though less pronounced and with higher selectivities around 80 %, was observed for 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst. For the 9.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst the comparable increase of the methanol and CO formation rates with increasing pressure results in an essentially constant selectivity of ∼88 %, independent of the total pressure (Fig. 2c). Note that we also tested the catalytic performance of the pure ZnO supports under identical reaction conditions. Both methanol and CO formation were below the detection limits of the GC of 20 and 5 ppm. Therefore, the presence of Au NPs is mandatory for measurable activity. 3.2 Structural characterization of the catalysts The specific surface areas of the different catalysts, determined by N2 adsorption, were found to be rather similar for the different catalysts (Table 2). Therefore, effects on the catalyst performance resulting from the specific surface area of the ZnO supports can be excluded. The crystal structure and the particle / crystallite sizes of the three Au/ZnO catalysts directly after calcination were probed by XRD measurements. The diffractograms reveal a pure wurtzite structure of ZnO (Fig. S2). The ZnO crystallite sizes were calculated from the XRD reflection at 36.2 ° ((101) reflection), yielding sizes around 25 and 40 nm, respectively (Table 2). Also here the differences are rather small. Overall, the close agreement in the BET surface area, phase composition and crystallite size of the ZnO supports indicates that the differences in the support material play a minor role for the differences in catalytic performance. From the Au reflection at 38.2 ° ((100) reflection), we also calculated the Au crystallite sizes, which results in values of 19 nm and 25 nm for the 9.5 and 16.5 wt.% catalysts, respectively, while for the low loading catalysts we did not see any Au-related reflections. The Au particle size distributions of the Au/ZnO catalysts were evaluated also from HAADF-STEM images, both directly after calcination and after the reaction sequence (details see Experimental). Representative STEM images of the catalysts as well as the resulting particle size distributions are presented in Fig. 3 . The difference in the absolute values of the mean particle sizes determined by XRD and STEM imaging is likely due to texture effects in the XRD measurements. In particular for the 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst the size difference between the ZnO crystallites and the Au NPs does not seem to be that big, with about a factor of 2 in between. Here one has to consider, however, that due to aggregation of crystallites the ZnO particles are significantly bigger. This is evident already from the STEM images in Fig. 3. Furthermore we would like to note that the Au NPs are more hemispherical than spherical, indicative of a distinct interface formation (see high resolution STEM images in Figs. 3 and S3). Similar STEM measurements performed after the complete reaction sequence, from 5 to 50 bar, revealed only negligible changes in the mean Au particle size, with a slight increase from 2.2 ± 0.5 to 2.6 ± 0.5 nm for the 1.0 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst, and essentially constant values for the 9.5 wt.% and the 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst. Based on the mean Au particle sizes and the respective loadings we calculated the length of the perimeter of the interface between ZnO support and Au NPs as well as the accessible Au surface area per gram catalyst, assuming hemispherical particles with a diameter corresponding to the mean particle size (see Table S1). The differences between the interface perimeter lengths of the different catalysts are rather small, with essentially similar values for the high loading catalysts, while it is by slightly more than a factor of 2 higher for the 1.0 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst (Table S1). Comparable results were obtained also for the accessible Au surface area, with the only difference that in this case the value of the low-loading catalyst was lower than that of the high-loading catalysts, by a factor of slightly more than 2 (Table S1). These rather small differences can be explained by the partly compensating effects of increasing particle size and increasing Au loading. More information on the structural changes of the Au NP induced by the reaction was obtained from changes in CO adsorption. CO adsorption (under steady-state conditions) was probed by in situ DRIFTS measurements at −140 °C (Fig. 4 a, b). The corresponding raw spectra and the background spectra are shown in Fig. S4. Starting with the freshly calcined catalysts, the 1.0 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst showed a sharp band located at 2100 cm−1, which was previously assigned to CO adsorbed on Au° sites [20,21]. The calcined 9.5 and 16.5 wt.%-Au/ZnO catalysts exhibit a broad peak with a main maximum at 2121 cm−1 and a shoulder at 2105 cm−1 (Fig. 4a). Bands around 2120 cm−1 were previously assigned to CO coadsorbed with oxygen on Au nanoparticles [22], and the signal around 2105 cm−1 is in the frequency range typical for COad on Au° sites [20,21]. Finally, there is a small band at 2148 cm−1, which is close to the band reported recently for CO adsorbed on Au2O3 at 2156 cm−1 [23]. Accordingly, we assign this to CO adsorbed on oxidized Au sites. It should be noted that CO adsorbed on ZnO leads to a band at 2181 cm−1 [21,24], and therefore can be excluded from these spectra. The higher content of coadsorbed oxygen and oxidized Au sites on the 9.5 and 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalysts after calcination compared to the 1.0 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst may be related to a lower reactivity of small Au nanoparticles for oxygen adsorption, which was reported already in an earlier study [25]. Alternatively, one might also assume that the Oad species formed on the smaller Au NPs of the 1.0 wt.%-Au/ZnO are more reactive towards CO than the Oad species on the bigger NPs of the 9.5 wt.% and 16.5 wt.%-Au/ZnO catalysts, and therefore are preferentially removed during exposure to CO. However, considering the very low temperature (−140 °C) of the CO adsorption experiments and the fact that we did not see significant changes in the intensity of this band (2120 cm−1) with time, except for an initial intensity increase (in the first ∼2 min), we favor the first explanation. In the spectra of the spent Au/ZnO catalysts, collected after reaction (5−50 bar, 240 °C), the intensity of COad bands was much lower than after calcination. Furthermore, all catalysts showed only a single band around 2100 cm−1, which for the 1.0 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst was exactly at 2100 cm−1, while for the 9.5 and 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalysts this was at 2104 cm−1. The other bands disappeared completely after the reaction, indicating complete reduction of the oxidized Au species existing after calcination. This observation also supports our assignment of the band at 2148 cm−1: While based on its frequency it could also be related to CO adsorbed on a thin layer of ZnO (mono- or bilayer) on the Au nanoparticles, considering the recent report of a band at 2138–2146 cm−1 for CO adsorbed on similar layers on Ag(111) [26], such ZnOx thin layers should be present after reaction rather than after calcination, as discussed later. The absence of such band on the spent catalysts, where we expect such layers to be present (see below), indicates that the bond of CO on these layers is too weak to be populated in the low-temperature adsorption experiments, in agreement with reports by Andersen et al. [26], where these species were found to desorb at 100 K. This latter explanation is supported by the fact that we also do not see any signals related to CO adsorption on the ZnO substrate, where CO is also weakly bound. For a quantitative assessment of the change of Au exposed surface, we evaluated the total intensity of the COad-Au bands in the range of 2050 to 2170 cm−1 (peak area). Considering that absolute COad coverages on different catalysts cannot precisely be determined from the intensities, due to possible differences in reflectivity etc., the small differences between the initial COad band intensities of the three catalysts agree reasonably well with our estimate of the accessible surface areas of the Au NPs, which based on the assumption of hemispherical Au NPs differ only by a factor of 2 between the low-loading catalyst and the high loading catalysts (Table S1, Supplementary Material). For the spent catalysts we found the COad-Au intensities to be significantly lower than after calcination, by about a factor of 3–8 (∼3.1 for 1.0 wt.%, ∼3.5 for 9.5 wt.% and ∼8.6 for the 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst). The pronounced losses in the intensity of the COad-Au bands give a direct impression of the reaction-induced loss in the number of adsorbed CO molecules. Considering that the reaction has a negligible effect on the Au NP size (Fig. 3), and assuming that i) the cross-sections for CO excitation on the respective catalysts and ii) the COad coverages on the accessible Au surface areas are similar under these conditions, these results point to a significant decrease in the accessible Au surface area. This is most likely caused by partial encapsulation of the Au NPs, as described by the concept of strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) [27,28]. Similar observations had been reported for Cu/ZnO catalysts before [29,30]. Though such effects were considered to be absent for Au nanoparticle catalysts for a long time [31,32], they have recently been reported for Au supported on TiO2 and on other reducible supports (Fe3O4, CeO2) after reductive high-temperature treatment [32]. For Au/ZnO overgrowth had been reported after an oxidative treatment previously, while reductive treatment was concluded to result in AuZn alloy formation [33]. While we cannot rule out alloying of small amounts of Zn into the Au nanoparticles under reaction conditions from our data, as it had been demonstrated for Cu/ZnO before [34,35], they clearly indicate a substantial loss of accessible surface area and hence overgrowth upon reductive treatment rather than upon oxidative treatment (calcination). Furthermore, the decay of the accessible surface area of the Au NPs appears to be more pronounced on the 16.5 wt.% than on the 9.5 and 1.0 wt.% Au/ZnO catalysts. 3.3 Catalyst surface composition - XPS results Furthermore, we examined the surface composition (Au : Zn and Au : Olattice surface ratios) of the Au/ZnO catalysts and their change upon reaction by ex situ XPS measurements, which were conducted both on the freshly calcined catalysts and on the spent catalyst after reaction under high pressures at 240 °C. Note that for the calibration of the binding energy scale we used the characteristic value of the Zn 2p3/2 peak in ZnO of 1021.5 eV [36]. The region of the Au 4f signal contains both the Au 4f and the Zn 3p peaks. The binding energy (BE) of the Au 4f7/2 peak is 83.8 ± 0.1 eV (Fig. 5 a, b), both for the calcined and the spent Au/ZnO catalysts, which is typical for metallic Au0 nanoparticles [36], and agrees also with previous findings for Au catalysts [37]. Here it should be noted that the concentration of oxidic Au surface species, whose presence was concluded from the small peak at 2148 cm−1 in the DRIFTS spectra, is too low to be resolved by XPS in the large background of metallic Au atoms. The BE of the Zn 3p3/2 peak of 88.7 ± 0.1 eV is characteristic for Zn2+ [33]. From the intensities of the Au 4f and the Zn 2p3/2 peaks, normalized by the respective atomic sensitivity factors, we determined the Au : Zn surface atomic ratios (Fig. 5c). As expected, this increases significantly with increasing Au loading, both for the calcined and the spent Au/ZnO catalysts, from 0.09 for the 1 wt.% to 0.23 for the 16.5 wt.% catalyst. The lower increase of this ratio as compared to the increase in Au loading is caused by the increasing Au particle sizes, which results in increasing absorption of the emitted Au 4f electrons by the Au NPs. After the reaction, this ratio was significantly smaller than before for the low-loading catalyst, while for the high-loading catalysts this effect was either absent (9.5 wt.% catalyst) or, on a relative scale, smaller (16.5 wt.% catalyst). This decrease in Au : Zn ratio is most simply explained by the partial overgrowth of the Au NPs by a ZnOx layer, though other explanations such as surface alloying of reduced Zn into the Au NPs during the reaction (see above) are possible as well. Therefore we see these XPS data mainly as further support of the conclusion of partial ZnOx overgrowth derived low-temperature CO adsorption data. The smaller size of this effect as compared to the accessible surface area probed by CO adsorption results from the fact that XPS probes over several nm in depth, as determined by the mean free path of the photoelectrons. Therefore, absorption by ZnOx is less effective. The smaller effect on the high-loading catalysts, despite the significant decrease in the accessible surface area also on these catalysts, can be explained by the fact that for these big particles electron absorption by the thin oxide layer plays a lesser role compared to the small Au particles in the 1 wt.% catalyst. The O 1s spectra were fitted with three different components, both for the calcined and the spent Au/ZnO catalysts (Fig. S5). The first component at 530.3 eV was attributed to lattice oxygen [38,39], a second one at 531.7 eV is characteristic for adsorbed OH groups [40], but has also been attributed to lattice O connected to a Zn2+ ion with an oxygen vacancy in its immediate vicinity [38]. The third component at 532.9 eV may contain contributions from surface formates [40] and surface methoxy groups [41,42]. Since the binding energy of the Zn 2p peak is little sensitive to the Zn oxidation state and hence cannot be used for identifying changes in the ZnO reduction state, we characterized the formation of O-vacancies during the reaction by comparing the atomic Zn : O ratios in the surface region from the intensity of the Zn 2p3/2 peak at 1021.5±0.1 eV and of the O 1s component(s) characteristic for ZnO lattice oxygen, considering also the respective atomic sensitivity factors [36]. This ratio is expected to increase after reaction compared to the fully oxidized sample (i.e., after calcination) if O-vacancies are formed in the near-surface region of ZnO. For all calcined Au/ZnO catalysts, this evaluation results in an atomic Zn : Olatt ratio of 0.82 ± 0.02, while for the spent Au/ZnO catalysts this value changed to 1.01 for 1.0 wt.%, 0.90 for the 9.5 wt.%, and 0.84 for the 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst. This points to a loss of lattice oxygen on the spent catalyst, which assuming that after calcination ZnO is stoichiometric, reflects the formation of O-vacancies during the high-pressure reaction (5−50 bar). This result agrees well with our previous finding of oxygen vacancy formation on ZnO during methanol synthesis under identical reaction condition, which was identified directly by EPR spectroscopy [15]. The extent of O-vacancy formation decreases with increasing Au loading / Au particle size, from ∼19 % for the 1.0 wt.%, 9.0 % for the 9.5 wt.% and 2.5 % for the 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalyst, respectively. This trend resembles the trend in the Au-ZnO perimeter length (Table S1), with increasing perimeter length leading to enhanced O-vacancy formation, which is in good agreement with our previous conclusion for oxide supported catalysts that O-vacancy formation occurs mainly at the interface sites between Au NPs and the support [43–45]. An increasing O-vacancy formation we also observed for a set of Au/ZnO catalysts with increasing ZnO particle size, but constant Au loading / Au particle size under similar reaction conditions, which we had explained by an increasing density of Au NPs on the ZnO surface with increasing ZnO particle size [15]. In that case, because of the constant Au nanoparticle size, this is identical with an increasing Au perimeter length per ZnO surface area unit. An increasing tendency for O-vacancy formation with decreasing ZnO surface / increasing ZnO particle size was verified also by EPR measurements [15]. Finally, in the C 1s region (see Fig. S6), these three Au/ZnO catalysts show three components, including i) ubiquitous carbon species at 285.0±0.1 eV, ii) oxygenated carbon species such as methoxy species at 286.3±0.1 eV [40], and iii) a third peak at 289.0 ± 0.1 eV, which is assigned to formate and/or carbonate species [46,47]. The absence of a significant increase in C1 s intensity for all three Au/ZnO catalysts indicates that carbon species are not accumulated during reaction and hence are not responsible for the decay in the accessible Au surface area, supporting our previous conclusion of overgrowth by a ZnOx layer. 3.4 Discussion The data presented in this paper, together with findings reported previously [10,11], can be summarized and interpreted in the following way: 1 Kinetic measurements reveal distinct Au loading / Au particle size effects, with the activities for methanol and CO formation (Au-mass-normalized reaction rate, TOF) decreasing with increasing Au loading / Au particle size, while the selectivity for methanol formation increases. This decrease in activity is mainly due to the decreasing dispersion of the Au nanoparticles, i.e., a particle size effect. The small differences between catalyst-mass-normalized rates as well as previous findings [10,11] indicate that the decrease in Au-mass-normalized rates with Au particle size is largely compensated by an increase due to the increasing Au loading. In combination, these lead to small changes in the catalyst-mass-normalized rates. The increase in selectivity for methanol formation, in contrast, is dominated by Au particle size effects [11]. 2 These general trends are essentially independent of the reaction pressure, in the range between 5 bar and 50 bar. 3 Independent of the Au loading / Au particle size we find a substantial activation during the first 100 min on stream. Our data indicate that in the calcined state, directly after calcination, the catalysts are essentially inactive for methanol formation and become active only during the reaction. Similar observations we had previously reported for methanol formation on a commercial Au/ZnO catalyst and attributed to increasing O-vacancy formation until the steady-state concentration is reached [12,13]. Therefore, we assume that similar effects are present also on the catalysts used here. Considering that all of the freshly calcined catalysts are essentially inactive for methanol formation, the activation effect increases with decreasing particle size (higher steady-state rate). 4 The substantial losses in accessible Au surface area and in the Au : Zn surface atomic ratio during reaction compared to the freshly calcined Au/ZnO catalysts, which are indicated by low-temperature CO adsorption and by XPS, demonstrate a partial overgrowth of the Au NPs during the reaction, most likely by a ZnOx layer, as described by the SMSI concept. The tendency for overgrowth (loss of accessible surface) increases with increasing Au loading / Au particle size, which is opposite to the trend for O-vacancy formation during the reaction. Because of the counteracting effects of Au loading / Au particle size on the accessible Au surface area and on the Au perimeter length, however, a clear explanation of this trend is not possible at the moment. 5 Based on XPS results the surface atomic ratio of Zn : Olattice for the spent catalysts is lower than that of calcined catalysts from XPS results, pointing to the formation of O-vacancies during the reaction. This trend seems to scale with the perimeter length of the Au NPs, supporting previous conclusions that the O-vacancies are predominantly formed at the Au-oxide interface [43–45]. 6 Considering that under steady-state conditions part of the Au NP surface is not accessible, most likely due to overgrowth by a ZnOx layer, the number of accessible surface Au atoms under steady-state conditions is significantly smaller than that estimated from a hemispherical Au particle shape (Table S1). Correcting the numbers from Table S1 with the loss in accessible Au surface atoms from see Fig. 4, one obtains comparable numbers of accessible Au surface atoms per g catalyst for the spent 1 wt.% and 16.5 wt.% Au/ZnO catalysts, while for the spent 9.5 wt.% catalyst this would be somewhat higher. Also, for the number of Au perimeter atoms per g catalyst such correction needs to be considered, although in that case we have no quantitative numbers. 7 Overall, these numbers demonstrate that despite of the considerable changes in Au particle size and Au loading the numbers of (accessible) Au surface atoms and Au perimeter atoms per g catalyst change relatively little, which agrees rather well with the observation of rather similar catalyst-mass-normalized methanol formation rates for the 3 catalysts. The trends in the activation phase, where the methanol formation activity increases with time, while the number of accessible Au surface atoms decreases, essentially excludes a reaction model where the accessible Au surface atoms act as active sites. Better agreement is obtained for a reaction model where Au perimeter sites act as active sites and where the activity of these sites is enhanced upon O-vacancy formation and charge transfer to neighboring Au interface perimeter atoms. Alternatively, the ZnOx layer itself may act as active sites / phase for the methanol reactions, which is likely to grow with time. From the present and other reported data, we have no evidence for the latter mechanism, but also cannot exclude it. Here we need to keep in mind also that pure ZnO itself shows a low, but finite activity for methanol formation, which may be enhanced significantly by electronic modification. In any case, however, O-vacancy formation seems to play an important and presumably decisive role in the reaction, either directly, by increasing the activity of perimeter sites or indirectly, by driving the growth of and partial encapsulation by a ZnOx layer. Finally, AuZn alloy formation has not been reported so far, although very low concentrations of metallic Zn cannot be ruled out. 8 Finally, O-vacancy formation and partial ZnOx encapsulation not only affect the activity for methanol formation, but also lead to significant changes in the selectivity for methanol formation. Obviously, the increase in activity for methanol formation and for CO formation induced by these effects is different, which means that the optimum state of the active site for these reactions is different. This is indicated already by the fact that CO formation is active already at the very beginning of the activation phase. Therefore, one would not expect similar effects for these competing reactions, and thus distinct changes in the selectivity are likely. In combination, these data demonstrate that increasing the metal loading of Au/ZnO catalysts in the ‘green’ methanol synthesis from CO2 and H2, to reduce the amount of catalyst required for reaching technically interesting higher conversions, is economically little attractive. While larger Au particle sizes are beneficial for increasing the selectivity for methanol formation in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, their activity for methanol formation, as given by the Au-mass normalized rates, decreases rapidly, due to the rapid decay of their dispersion with increasing Au particle size. This trend is also valid when going to higher Au loading, which in most cases goes along with larger particle sizes. Increasing the Au loading would only become attractive if this is achieved at constant Au particle size, e.g., by deposition of prefabricated Au nanoparticles [10]. But also in such case the Au-mass-normalized conversion to methanol (methanol formation rate) in CO2-free (CO/H2) and CO2-containing (CO/CO2/H2) synthesis gas was found to decrease with Au loading [10]. Future work in this direction, on Au loading effects, should concentrate on two aspects, i) reducing the increase in Au particles size when increasing the Au loading, e.g., by the use of preformed colloidal Au nanoparticles, and test the effect on methanol formation from CO2/H2 mixtures, and ii) to approach higher, technically relevant conversions. 4 Conclusion Aiming at a reduction of the catalyst mass in a potential application of Au/ZnO catalysts for ‘green’ methanol synthesis from CO2/H2 gas mixtures, we have studied the effect of increasing the Au loading on the performance of these catalysts. The catalysts were prepared by a deposition-precipitation procedure, using the same type of ZnO support (comparable specific surface area). Combining kinetic measurements at up to 50 bar with different techniques for catalyst characterization, we found that i) increasing the Au loading results in a pronounced increase of the Au particle size, and that ii) this goes along with a rapid decrease of the activity (Au-mass normalized rate or TOF) of the catalysts and an enhanced selectivity with increasing Au loading. The former results from the significant decrease of the Au particle dispersion in combination with the increasing Au loading, while the latter is solely attributed to Au particle size effects. iii) Independent of the Au loading the catalysts are highly stable over 16 h on stream, both structurally and chemically, except for a partial encapsulation of the Au NPs, as described by the concept of SMSI, which is associated with a slight reduction of the ZnO surface. This, however, does not hinder a significant activation of the catalysts at the beginning of the reaction, which was observed for all of them. coredata.dc:description: Methanol synthesis by CO2 reduction is an important approach for energy storage. Aiming at a reduction of the catalyst mass in technical applications, we have investigated the influence of increasing Au loading on the performance of Au/ZnO in methanol and CO formation from CO2 reduction. Using the same type of ZnO support, increased Au loading resulted also in a pronounced increase in Au particle size. The Au-mass-normalized reaction rate for methanol formation and TOF decrease with increasing Au loading/particle size, while the selectivity for methanol formation increases. CO adsorption monitored by in situ FTIR revealed a pronounced decrease of the accessible Au surface area during reaction, independent of the Au loading, pointing to a partial encapsulation of the Au nanoparticles by a partly reduced ZnOx, as described by SMSI effects. Possible reasons responsible for these effects and Au loading/size effects therein are discussed, strategies for future work are outlined.
coredata.dc:title: Performance of Au/ZnO catalysts in CO2 reduction to methanol: Varying the Au loading / Au particle size
